(4) The Persian empire³ had long been falling into decay. Extending as it did from the western coast of Asia Minor to the Jaxartes and the Indus, it comprised within its borders many races speaking divers tongues and widely differing from one another in their seelings and modes of life. Some of these races had never been thoroughly subdued: indeed of the hill tribes nominally included in the empire, while some professed allegiance to the Great King but set his commands at nought‚ others openly refused to make a show of submissim, and even levied black-mail on the monarch and his officers for safe conduct through their passes. The only way in which it was possible to rule such a vast domain was by parcelling it 0111 among governors and making them severally responsible for their districts. Thus the Persian empire was divided into satrapies4 each under the rule of a governor called the Satrap. somewhat resembling 3 Turkish Pacha.
